Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations
What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class
Comments_List:
Skills: Systems thinking, writing briefs, causal loop diagrams, multi-criteria decision analysis

Insights: conversations and domain-specific talks with a number of thought-leaders from industry, media, environmental justice, science, and more

It is an amazing course that brought me to think of many aspects that I have not thought before, or at least not in an integrated way.  I learned different ways to approach a problem and learned to study a problem in a broader scope as a systematic scope. I learned more about the current regulations and roles of different stakeholders. Also, the course brought me a positive attitude towards the tough problems currently out there.

The idea of a systems thinking approach was helpful but if anything, just a seed was planted. The course lacked the discussion of learning the framework (also is there anything beyond Donnella Meadows?) and applying the perspectives we were hearing from guest speakers. Instead, this process was left as GROUP WORK (which has an entirely different set of challenges compounded  by attempting to learn the framework, formulate one's perspective and then advocate for that perspective with a group that lacked cohesion or trust because the work up until that point had been individual).

I learned how to make causal loop diagrams, conduct multi-criteria decision analysis, and think in systems! I learned so much. It has really changed the way that I think about problems and I think it will be immensely valuable to me in the future. In particular, it challenged me to think about SOLUTIONS rather than just environmental problems. This is not something you typically learn how to do in environmental courses, and I think we need much more of.

I learned how to think about a problem within a larger system and from a variety of perspectives. Since this semester focused on toxic chemicals, I have a deeper appreciation for green chemistry solutions and am much more aware of potentially hazardous chemicals in consumer products.

This class helped develop my critical thinking skills. It was my first introduction to systems thinking and causal loop diagrams, and it was helpful to have to come up with these analyses on our own for the final paper.

I also developed skills in writing briefing papers. The three page limit per paper was useful in helping me think about what the most important points were and how to highlight those points.

The guest lecturers were also a highlight. It was very interesting to have different people come into class with different perspectives. The opportunity to have lunch with the speakers was a great benefit.

I learned a lot about my chemical! I feel like I also learned a lot about the system of pollution, toxicants, clean up and policy that allows these problems to persist.

The speakers were incredible.

I learned how to approach the complex problems that we face in the environmental field. I learned just how complex those problems can be, with multiple stakeholders and their conflicting views, and how scientific consensus can be influenced by external factors. Learning about causal loop diagrams was also super useful, something I would like to apply to future problems.

I learned a systems thinking approach to problem solving. Mapping out issues and their causes through causal loop diagrams helped me visualize where it is most important to intervene to find a solution. I also learned how to briefly summarize the most important points from different angles of problem solving. Finally, I learned the dos and don'ts of team operations.
A framework for systems thinking, understanding how to use conceptual modelling software, and a deep understanding of the intricacies of chemistry+industry+society.

This course was by far the best one I took this semester. It truly transformed the way I approach and think about solving problems and really taught me to respect and consider the interconnectedness of different parts of a system.

Introduction to concept of systems thinking. I felt like I learned more though about the regulation of chemicals and the actors within this field, which was valuable for me given my interests in environmental health.
The course introduced me to system thinking methods and multi-criteria analysis needed to prepare a holistic briefing paper for the policy maker.
System dynamics and problem analysis skills
Systems thinking, chemistry, products, health.

I developed a deeper understanding of the systems thinking approach, and the complexity of solving environmental issues. I learnt a lot about toxic chemicals and the interactions with multiple stakeholders. I developed the skill of reading papers and articles and extracting the main ideas into a briefing paper for decision makers.
How to write a brief, the ins and outs of problems related to chemicals in the environment
I learned how to apply systems thinking to a relevant issue, by analyzing all perspectives, and using problem statements, causal loop diagrams, and multi-criteria decision analysis.

Integrated decision making 
Identifying issues with the current systems and processes in which we work in as environmental professionals.
Also learnt a lot about chemicals!
Thinking in systems. Understanding the regulatory, social, financial, economic facets of the chemicals industry. How to write an effective policy brief.

The biggest skill I gained in class was learning to write briefing papers and to write concisely, shaving paragraphs down to key information. I also learned out to sift through a lot of information quickly in order to grasp the gist of it. Finally, I learned valuable tools in systems thinking, including multi-criteria decision analysis and causal loop diagrams.
Research and writing skills for the briefing papers.

- an understanding of systems thinking
- exposure to many different perspectives around the issue of toxic chemicals (scientist, NGO advocate, chemical industry leader)
- an understanding of the system which keeps a toxic chemical in use
- many aspects of the chemical (chemical properties, how it is used, how it is marketed, etc). Good holistic understanding.
This course taught me the basics of systems thinking and then provided an opportunity to apply that framework to a practical toxic (and wicked) problem.

I developed a deeper understanding of the interconnected and complex systems that shape the world around me, especially as related to environmental and social problems. I also developed group management skills and the ability to efficiently synthesize large amounts of research into concise, readable briefings.
Systems thinking
They aligned well!
Way beyond my expectation.

I had heard such wonderful things about the course from last year and I thought a similar magic would ensue. Be it the topic, the class, the room--the semester felt rushed (we barely debriefed guest speakers) and lacked a coherent co-teaching dynamic (classes were run by Julie and Paul was there to make us laugh, or when his schedule allowed for it, or to deliver one, 20 minute lecture and introduce guests).
Very well! We had fascinating speakers and the professors were great at lecturing.

I wanted to have a better understanding of the chemical industry and potential green chemistry alternatives, and this class did a good job of exposing me to this complex system and made me think about the problem from a variety of perspectives.
This class met and exceeded expectations. The guest speakers each added something unique. It was also nice to have Paul in the class to talk to us about chemistry. I
I wish we would have learned how to write the papers. I wish we would have written them together, or all did a practice one on the same chemical.
I was drawn to the class because of its focus on tackling complex problems with a systems approach, and I am happy to say that is exactly what I got.
Everything was more in depth than I imagined, but in a positive way. Most assignments require a lot of time.
Very well
Surpassed my expectations. I learned even more than I thought I would and ended up feeling much more passionate about chemicals than I ever thought I could.

I expected there to be more content about systems thinking than toxic chemicals. I would have liked there to be more class time spent on multi criteria analysis or causal loops. That being said, I enjoyed the guest lectures and our deep-dive into one chemical, and feel like I can point to my knowledge/papers when I apply for jobs.
Overall, my expectations were met.
Class really didnt expand in SD as much as expected,
Very well.

The briefing papers were great assignments to develop the skills of analyzing, processing and writing.
The class definitely aligned with my expectations.
Well
It was spot on!

Would have preferred to spend more time on systems thinking concepts and tools, and less on chemicals/toxics specifically. For this reason, the knowledge, skills, and insights from the class came up slightly short of my expectations.
The skills I gained align well with my expectations with the course.
More or less. I expected the technical knowledge to be deeper.
Very well
This class was exactly what I expected it to be. I was able to expand my limited knowledge of systems thinking and then also to learn about a real world toxin and ways to intervene in the system.

This class met expectations overall, but the end of the semester felt rushed. I know that this is because we managed to fit an incredible amount of information and guest speakers, but it would have been helpful to have more discussion/lecture time to circle back to systems analysis once we'd really gotten to analyze a system.

Paul and Julie are inspirations! I feel like I learned a lot from them, and can feel myself approaching problems differently already.

The semester felt very separated between early lectures by the professors and later talks by the speakers. It would be nice to have some more integration.

It would also be helpful to start the briefing papers perhaps a week earlier, so that we have more time to spend on the final project.
It is an amazing course. It is perfect.

Strengths -- dynamic, involves a little taste of everything such has heavy writing with clear and thorough feedback, hefty reading, guest speakers, group work, independent work, and some class discussion.

Weaknesses -- too many themes at once (only a select few are studying your same case study), uncomfortable room with clunky chairs

Strengths: depth of knowledge of professors, who really care about the material and the class. TAs were also helpful and frequently available to meet outside of class. I particularly appreciated that the course forces students to think from multiple perspectives, develop skills in writing briefing papers, and think about solutions. 

Weaknesses: The class seemed a little disorganized at times - and sometimes we were inundated with Canvas announcements. But relative to the strengths, these are minor points.

The systems thinking component of the course could have been explored more deeply. While the guest speakers were overall great, the course would have benefited from having a few more grounded discussions to process the information.

The instructors and the TAs did a very good job in structuring the course. The lectures and class discussions were phenomenal, and the order of the briefing papers made a lot of sense.

This might be hard to do (due to scheduling issues), but there were a few speakers that came that said things that would have been interesting to think about for briefing papers that were already submitted. It would be nice if there were someway to go back and add those things somewhere during the course instead of sitting on our thoughts until the final paper.

It also would have been interesting to have more time for class discussion. We had a lot of speakers and I think only one full class session to unpack everything that we heard.

One more small thing - it would have been helpful to have office hour scheduling/times available sooner.
Not enough guidance on the papers. Rubrics would be helpful.
Strengths:  Systems thinking, complex problems, brought in variety of speakers that shared experience, and we were encouraged to challenge them.

Strengths - very passionate professors, influencing speakers including one that was brilliant yet controversial (important for real world challenges) and heavy class engagement. All of this was very helpful to also keep up with current environmental events.

Weaknesses - writing briefing papers is not as simple as it seems. There should be more training time to do this (at least one or part of a class that breaks down an example brief). The TAs were great, but sometimes their thoughts didn't align with what the professors wanted us to focus on in our papers. I would have also loved to learn more about solutions/the process of creating them after class discussions (those typically took up a lot of time so I understand that there wasn't much time left for that).
I enjoyed getting all the different perspectives of the guest speakers. The lunch afterwards was also valuable.

Other than the very heavy workload, I have no complaints. The instructors are outstanding, the course content was germane and interesting, and the speakers perfectly complemented the course content. This course should truly be required for all students completing an MEM program. It's so critical to instill a systems thinking approach to problem solving in future environmental leaders.

Strengths - the amount of work and research required to write the briefing papers forced me to engage with the course and learn a ton about the chemical system broadly and my chemical, generally. I felt way more engaged with this course than others. I thought the guest lectures were all really interesting.

Weaknesses - We spent most of the semester looking at each aspect of the system but not how they worked together. I think there could have been more time dedicated to that, mainly in the form of thinking of solutions and writing our final paper. It was a huge last-week push to write that, and I think it could have been higher quality if we had had about 2 or 3 weeks. I also think the guest speakers could have better represented the system if they had spoken on the same day and had a panel discussion with us in class.

One of then biggest strengths of the course is the systems thinking approach. It was interesting to look at the chemical from the policy, technology, communications etc. perspectives. However, it would be even more interesting to prepare similar briefings on the chemical for the decision-makers not only in policy but also in industry and NGOs. 

I enjoyed receiving a detailed feedback on each of my papers - it helped to look at the chemical from a different point of view and identify the gaps. 

I enjoyed the guest speakers - some of the lunch conversations were really inspiring and enlightening. However, the abundance of the guest speakers could not substitute the need to get a more specific knowledge on how the FDA, EPA and other governmental agencies interact and work. These questions emerged once we started to work on our final paper - it seemed quite difficult to come of with the feasible recommendations without solid understanding of these basic facts and interrelations.

It would be great if more attention was given to the format of the briefing paper that can be actually presented to the EPA or FDA. I find it to be a very important detail that could make the course much more applicable to reality.
Smaller class, more clarity between TA's and professor, having such a large number of themes reduces some level of discussion about the topics, more focus in SD and less about the topic (Chemical)

Strengths: great organization, engaging lecturers and guest speakers, project-based, relevant, engaging, good assignments.

Weaknesses: started out a bit slow. Don't learn about other chemicals/student groups until the very end, which ends up being only a 15 min pres.

The professors were extremely engaged and passionate about the topics, it was extremely exciting to go to class. The lecturers were very interesting and brought their insight from different stakeholder positions.
During the semester we did a deep analysis of the problems surrounding our chemical, however we did not dive into solutions or recommendations until the last paper. It would have been useful to have more time to elaborate the final paper and be able to analyze alternatives. Regarding the feedback received from the papers, the level of detail received was very different from one paper to the other; even between group members we received different recommendations regarding for example citation, format and content, and this generated confusion. During the semester it was difficult to have a clear understanding of what was expected in the papers and how they were graded.
Guest speakers were great, assignments were intense but useful for learning

The professors were deeply engaged and engaging. The assignments were relevant, had clear expectations, and helped build valuable skills. The introductions to systems thinking at the start of the course were fascinating. It was exciting to have so many prominent spokespeople come into class, but it also felt difficult to integrate learnings from then since we had so few opportunities to discuss them as a class. When we did discuss, it was in a large group. I think it would be helpful to create smaller discussion groups of students to discuss the speakers and how they relate to our topic and systems thinking approach. Additionally, I think we could have had fewer speakers, and had more time at the end of the semester to work on our projects with our groups.

Well structured and implemented! Nothing should change. 
Group work should however be encouraged at the start of classes.

The guest speakers were really interesting, but comprised nearly half of the class time that I felt could have been used for class discussion or more in-depth lectures about systems thinking. I think a panel session with a couple of the guest speakers interacting together would have been much more useful, than hearing each of them in isolation, as this would be a better representation of how stakeholders interact in the real world and would have opened up more class sessions for other activities. 

I felt expectations for final projects/presentations were poorly communicated, and students were not given benefit of the doubt for the miscommunication by professors/TAs. Final presentations during reading period was never identified in the syllabus, and was mentioned only briefly during class during the week that many students were away for the COP conference.

I really valued the guest lecturers and thought it was cool to hear from people across the spectrum of perspectives. That said, a lot of class time was dedicated to guest lectures and, as a result, I felt like there was a bit of a disconnect between the systems thinking skills learned during the first few weeks of class, the guest lectures, and the final white paper. I would have liked more time practicing and developing the systems skills before having to dive back into them after a couple of months for the white paper. It wasn't entirely clear how they fit back in with the briefing papers we had been writing, and it seemed like more time could have been spent on prepping for the white paper and linking the class components together. I thought the teaching team was really great! Feedback and standards seemed to differ at times from one TA or Professor to the other--perhaps consistency in grading could have been improved. Communication became a little rough at the end of the semester with unclear deadlines and expectations for the final paper and presentation, but for entirety of the semester up until that point, communication was clear and effective. Overall, I really enjoyed this class and felt like I learned a lot.
Strength: Varied speakers talking about diverse topics. It could be improved by including more articulating sessions.
Strengths: Amazing teaching, great material, great structure

The guest speakers were definite strengths.

I would have liked for some more guidance from Paul and Julie (I.e. Lectures).

It also wasn't clear to the class or on the syllabus that there would be presentations at the end of the semester. This should be made clear at the beginning of the semester so students are able to plan effectively.

This was an excellent course! It was very work intensive and at times stressful, but I learned a lot and developed important and applicable skills. The transition from independent briefing papers to group work and synthesis was a bit rocky and rushed. It would have been helpful to start that process a bit earlier, or with clearer understandings of what was expected of us. Perhaps an encouragement or requirement to share findings and understandings during group check-ins once or twice during the semester? My group started many interesting discussions regarding our system that we weren't able to fully explore or resolve due to time constraints at the end of the semester.
Providing more examples of guidelines to briefing papers and where to find information
strongly recommend.

Overall, an interesting course that is very front loaded with policy briefs. Course success really depends on case study. From what I have heard, I believe "place-based" topics (ie Flint) were much more successful than the concept based approach (ie toxins).
Make sure you carve out sufficient time to invest in the briefing papers and work overall!
Be prepared to put in a lot of time for the briefing papers, and think outside the box for potential solutions to complex environmental problems.
Be prepared to do a lot of work and thinking critically. It is well worth it to develop a more effective way of approaching problems.

This course will set you up to approach the complex problems we'll face as environmental managers. This semester, it was focused on toxic substances. Even though I probably won't focus on toxicology or chemistry, I'll be able to take the skills and knowledge learned in the class and apply it to other areas.

This class takes up a lot of time so do not procrastinate. Go to office hours. When it's time for group presentations at the end of the course, DO NOT all speak. Everything seems more disorganized and those presentations typically took up the most time.
The relentless nature of the papers for the first several weeks are intense and difficult, but very worthwhile and a good exercise. You'll gain a lot from this course, whatever the case study is.
Take this course, you won't regret it. Regardless of the topic, take it as you will gain invaluable perspective.

Make sure you don't have more than one other heavy workload course the semester that you take Science to Solutions. The briefing papers took me about 10-15 hours during the week that they were due. Also, if you have no interest in the topic at hand (this semester - toxic chemicals), you should consider taking another course that is more relevant and will teach you systems thinking.

Class currently does not cover Sd as much as expected, and half is devoted to the specific topic foundations, (Chemicals), if its a Sd class more time should be devoted to system dynamics and build in previous technical foundations
take it!
I believe this course will be helpful to any FES student interested in solving complex environmental problems.
Very useful for all students, irrespective of your background whether it be social sciences, physical sciences, regulatory, etc.

I would suggest taking this class if the topic aligns with your focus/area of interest. I am not planning to pursue a concentration in chemicals/toxics, and felt the class focused too much on the specific topic (or the "what") rather than teaching the systems thinking approach (or the "how"), and felt I could have perhaps had a comparatively more valuable experience if I instead took a course within my area of interest.
Devote enough time to briefing papers. Particularly, to conducting research. The course is a good choice if you are interested in a holistic, systems perspective.
Don't underestimate the amount of time required by briefing papers!!

If you want to be put in touch with the leaders in the field, take this course for the guest lectures and lunches. 

Paul and Julie also have immense experience and are incredible resources when trying to address these wicked problems.

This course is worth every late night and stressful last-minute deadline submission. The systems thinking model is essential for effective problem solving on environmental issues. Even if the focus of the case studies is not directly applicable to your interests, take this class.
